page.title: 04FARMING IN ASKHAM
page.content: Manor Farm is about 200 acres in size,a third of which is down to grass,the remainder for growing cereals. There are 60 British Friesian in the herd and 60 other cattle bred for herd replacements or for beef.The cows each average 6,300 litres of milk a year.Recently imposed quotas will force this to be reduced. In winter the cows are fed on a compound dairy feed and grass silage.They live in a covered yard until spring when they are turned out to graze on grass. In late spring the grass is cut and baled to conserve it. The cereals grown are winter wheat and winter barley, producing an average of 3 tonnes of grain per acre. The crop rotation is grass, grass, w. wheat, wheat w.barley w.barley.(6). Manure is spread on the grass in the 2nd.year and ploughed in before the first winter wheat crop.
